Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Sonic Logging the NEEM Corehole, Greenland
Award.AbstractNarration:
Past deep ice cores recovered from the Greenland Ice Sheet have failed to obtain intact Eemian ice, ice from the last interglacial period. The recent NEEM effort has successfully recovered ~150 m of such ice. The proposed continuous sonic monitoring of the ice fabric will resolve small scale variability that is missed by the traditional techniques used in thin section analyses of ice cores, which tend to under-sample the core. The scales to be recovered with the sonic sampling are more comparable to those that can be observed with new gas-sampling technologies. The proposed work would add to the physical data set required to fully interpret data being recovered from the NEEM ice core, such as the gas content analyses used to infer past atmospheric conditions. The presence of a special USGS winch this summer, a winch required for the operation of University of Washington instrument proposed for deployment, and the planned abandonment of the NEEM field camp after the summer of 2012, make this proposal appropriate for a RAPID award.

Broader Impacts:

The project will provide international experience for a graduate student and support for a female scientist during the formative years of her career. It will contribute to international collaborations with Scandinavia.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Introduction

The North Greenland EEMian Ice Drilling (NEEM) ice core is the only Greenland ice core recovered to date that contains a complete record of the Eemian interglacial (130,000-115,000 years ago). This ice core is currently being interpreted by scientists for its record of climate history. Our work contributes to the interpretation of accumulation-rate history and deformation history of the surrounding ice. Of particular interest, the core contains the first recoverable fold ever reported in an ice core. The folding caused certain time periods recorded in the ice core to appear multiple times and upside down. Since the folding is recoverable, NEEM researchers have been able to “unfold” the fold to determine the original order the ice layers were in before folding. Recent new observations from deep ice-penetrating radar images collected by NASA's IceBridge Program show that folding of the deep layers is relatively common across central and northern Greenland.

The value of sonic logging and fabric studies

The goal of our project was to measure the velocity of sound through ice, which tells us about the effective viscosity of the ice. An ice crystal has a layered structure – similar to a deck of cards. It is much easier to shear an ice crystal along the molecular layers than to deform it any other way. Because of the 'slipperiness' of shearing along the layers within the ice crystal, the orientation of ice crystals matters.

The orientation of a single crystal is defined by its c-axis, the vector that points perpendicular to the molecular layers. Crystal fabric, then, is the statistical distribution of c-axes directions. Deep in an ice sheet, the deformation tends to rotate the crystals until most of the crystals have their layers oriented horizontally and c-axes oriented vertically. In this deep ice, the viscosity is different depending on whether you are shearing or squeezing the ice. As the ice in an ice sheet continues to deform, ice fabric continues to evolve. Fabric thus serves both as a record of ice sheet dynamics, and it influences modern deformation. Understanding the deformation and dynamic history at an ice core site is critical to interpreting ice core records – in particular the accumulation rate history.

We measure crystal fabric by measuring the velocity of sound through the ice because ice crystals transmit sound waves at different speeds depending on the orientation of the molecular layers. We can then compare this measurement to thin slices (“thin sections”)of the ice observed through crossed polarizing lenses to further understand the fabric that are measured every 10-50m. 

Intellectual merit and broader impacts

This study is the first sonic-log based crystal fabric study of ice in the zone of the first identified, recoverable folds in an ice core. The interplay between folding, crystal fabric, and ice rheological behavior is a mostly uninvestigated area that may prove critical for characterizing and modeling ice sheet dynamics. Spatial variations in fabric may influence folding. Incorporating the rheological effects of fabric should yield better model inputs and parameterization for the physics of ice flow for ice sheet models.

Furthermore, the ice in the NEEM core includes the only complete Northern Hemisphere record of the warmer-than-present Eemian period (approximately 130 kyr before present), with potential analogues to future climate change scenarios.  A Greenland-wide melt event was observed for the first time in historical record during the summer of 2012; several similar events have been identified during the Eemian portion of this ice core.
